reasoning:
The critique targets an implicit assumption that future “compromise/moral diversity” works like roughly symmetric bargaining/aggregation, arguing instead that replication and control of bottlenecks makes power highly asymmetric and institutionally path-dependent. This is relevant, but not fully central: the essay’s main thesis is that near-best futures are a narrow target because value is fragile and many moral views are ‘fussy’ (including via population ethics, digital welfare, bounded/unbounded value functions, etc.). Even if bargaining is asymmetric, that tends to make eutopia harder (supporting ‘no easy eutopia’) rather than refuting the core claim. Where it bites is on the essay’s occasional gestures that convergence/compromise might guide society toward the target and on how to think about concrete failure modes; falsifying the symmetry intuition would moderately weaken that part, but would not collapse the overall argument.

Strength is moderate: it plausibly shows an underanalyzed mechanism (power/replication) that could dominate outcomes and thus undermines any optimistic inference from “diverse values can compromise,” but it doesn’t substantially engage the essay’s main technical case that many moral value functions imply narrow targets even absent power struggles.

Correctness is fairly high: it’s reasonable that replication and control can distort representation and allocation, and the essay indeed does not do equilibrium political-economy analysis. Some wording overreaches (the essay doesn’t rely heavily on a ‘moral parliament’ model in this piece, and it already notes the voting-majority-by-replication risk), so not perfect.

Clarity is high and focused; little dead weight; it’s largely a single, coherent objection.
title: The paper fails to account for asymmetric power dynamics in future scenarios
